Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I'm gonna play it again...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You're not going to play it again.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Well, lemme play the other side then.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Now quit, Bobby. You said you're goin' a help me pick a song.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You said.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Well, lemme sing the one I picked an' see what you think...  "When there's a fire in your heart/Break the glass/Sound the alarm..."

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Oh, you prick...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: How 'bout if I just cut off your damn water?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'm too moved by your gentility to speak.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Sugar, you know how I feel about you, don't you? I'm just tryin' to get you to take an interest in my kind a things, an' what I'm tryin' to do with myself...  You know, there id'n anything in the world I wouldn't do for you, baby. I started livin' the day I found you, you know that?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You're playing the other side.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Cerveza.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Serveza yourself!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Now, now.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: No, dammit, I would easy.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: But you heal fast.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You can play the piano, an' your whole damn family can play on some type a musical instrument. An' all I'm askin' is for you to listen to my singing for one single little second...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: But you think you would? No, you're too damn selfish...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Why'nt you take 'at sign off your tit, Ray, an' let's go on out.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Out where?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I don't know, I'll holler up Elton an' Stoney...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I'll go out with you, or I'll stay here, and do anything you'd like for me to do... if you'll just do one thing. If you'll tell me that you love me.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You can sing the song.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You know what, you are never satisfied.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: That's right, hand.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Oh, now, baby...

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Your ball, Ray.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Is this suppose to be fun?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Go on, get up there...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Now don't loft it, just release it like I told you.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: The ball's too heavy for me, honey...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: It's not the damn ball.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I'm tryin', baby, so don't start gettin' mad now.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No, I'm not mad at you, hand. It'll be all right. Just spot and follow through...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Id'n he somethin' to see?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Right. Now show me a little somethin' this time, okay? Give me some form...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I can't help it, honey, the ball just keeps goin' cocky wobbly on me...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Will you just do what the hell I tell you...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I did, didn' I, El?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You got another ball comin'.

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Atta boy, Ray!

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: That was damn good, wad'n it? I finally did it...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah, great.  Why don't you throw Z's for 19 frames, and then roll a strike on the last ball in the last frame of a losing game? Just wonderful.

Speaker: twinky
Dialogue: Are you talking to us?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I'm gonna go wait in the car.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah, why don't you do that.

Speaker: stoney
Dialogue: Wait an I'll I go with you, honey...

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: We gotta get on home an' relieve the sitter. Why'nt you an' Ray come on over.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Okay. Go ahead. I'll settle up for the beers...  An' walk Rayette over with you, will you.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Can I get you anything else?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No. How much do I owe you?

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Five'll do it.

Speaker: twinky
Dialogue: We been wantin' to ask you something. Are you the guy on YV?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Am I on TV?

Speaker: twinky
Dialogue: She says you're the one that sells all the cars on TV.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well, I don't claim to have sold 'em all. They still have some left, I believe.

Speaker: betty
Dialogue: See, I told you it was him...  Your name's Donnie something, right?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I leave it to you.

Speaker: betty
Dialogue: My name is Shirley, but they call me Betty, and her name's Twinky.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Twinky?

Speaker: betty
Dialogue: Yeah, 'cause she's so "twinky"...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well, Betty and Twinky, it sure is nice talking to you girls. I just wish I had more time...

Speaker: betty
Dialogue: That's a wig you wear, isn't it?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: A wig?

Speaker: betty
Dialogue: Yeah, I told her it was you, but that you're wearing a wig, 'cause on TV you're mostly bald in the front.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah, I don't like to wear the wig on TV, because with two and a half million people watching you, you've gotta be sincere. I just like to wear it when I'm out slippin' around bowling alleys an' things like that. I think it gives me a little more class, don't you?

Speaker: twinky
Dialogue: Oh, definitely...

Speaker: betty
Dialogue: Yeah, but I can see a little bitty of the net up there, that's what give it away.

Speaker: twinky
Dialogue: It's so weird to see you in person, but that's who she says you are.

Speaker: betty
Dialogue: Aren't you.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah, you could say it's me.

Speaker: twinky
Dialogue: I'm gonna give you our number, Donnie, just in case...  We're both professionals, if you didn't guess.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well, you seem very professional...

Speaker: twinky
Dialogue: I always tell everyone the same thing. I got rolled and beat up real bad recently, and since then it's two for one, an' I work strictly in tandem with Betty...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah, I can see how she'd come in handy.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Come on. We're goin' over to Elton's.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I'm not.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You just going to sit there?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Okay. Hope no one hits on you.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I hope they do.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: See you later, then...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No one would want to hit on you, you look too pathetic.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You're the pathetic one, not me.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'm going on over there...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I'm not some piece a crap.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I know you're not.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You treat me like I was.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You go slippin' around in front a my face, an' in front a Elton an' Stoney. What do you imagine they think a someone you treat that way...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Now, hand...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You're goin' a find me dead one time.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Sssh, come on now...  Be a good girl.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: If you really want a get up an' leave me, you can read about it in the newsprint.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'm not going to get up an' leave you.  Now let's go over to El's an' have a good time.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Do you love me, Bobby?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well now, what do you think?

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: God, id'n she the cutest damn thing in your life!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Can you believe this shit?

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Give 'em the horn, Bob.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Look at these assholes! What the hell are they doing?!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I can't take this shit anymore.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Hey, get off my car!

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Where the hell's he goin'?

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Hey, Bob! Come on! Quit foolin' around!

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Shit, what's he doin'?

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: You better get your butt off there, Bob! Come on, now!!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I was with Elton last night, Ray.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You son of a bitch.

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: I swore to God I'd never hire on to this type a work again. Christ, I don't know how the hell I let you talk me into it...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Give me a swig, hon'.

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: You didn' know I was a derrickman once, did you?

Speaker: stoney
Dialogue: My brother Cruser, yeah...

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: I once hung suspendered 90 feet up on a tour, like a damn circus artist...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Honey, took at this little bugger.

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Near broke my damn neck...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Id'n he the cutest little guy?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Very cute... Put it down, an' let's go.

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: You know, you oughta get you one them things, Bob.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: An' I oughta live in a trailer park with my front teeth poked out...

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Well, what if she was, Bob? I can't see nothin' so bad in it...

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Hell, id'n it just somethin' to face up to? I'll tell you, somewhere along the line, you even get to likin' the whole idea...

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: I recall when Stoney first give me the news, I could a shit...

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Well, id'n that nice.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: It's ridiculous! I'm sitting here, listening to some asshole cracker compare his life to mine!

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: If you're sayin' you're somethin' better'n what I am, that's one thing. But I can't say much a someone who'd run off an' leave a woman in a situation like this an' feel easy about it. An' that's all I gotta say.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I hope that's all you gotta say, El, 'cause I'm about as tired of your mouth as I am workin' this stinkin' hole!

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Shit ass!!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Hey, Longcipher! I'm quitting!

Speaker: driller
Dialogue: I don't give a shit what you do. You ben more trouble than you're worth, an' I'm damn glad to be rid of both a you assholes.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Hey! What's goin' on?!

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Don't do that, Bob!! It's the Law!

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Sure as hell he wouldn' a done that if he'd known who you was... Would you, Bob?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Christ Almighty, what's happening here?

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: Okay, let him go.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Tell me what in the hell's going on, Elton!

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: I got accused a robbin' a fillin'station down in the Indian Nation, didn' I tell you...

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: I got wild an' jumped my bail...

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: Move it!

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: An' here they come runnin' after me a year later... Ain't that somethin'?

Speaker: elton
Dialogue: Tell Stoney for me, will you?! Tell her to come get me...

Speaker: twinky
Dialogue: Donnie, oh Donnie...

Speaker: first engineer
Dialogue: There she goes again.

Speaker: second engineer
Dialogue: My 1-year-old can carry a tune better than that.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: second engineer
Dialogue: I'd like to remind you again, this isn't an opera or a musical comedy.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Oh... I'm sorry. Was I singing again?

Speaker: second engineer
Dialogue: If you want to call it that.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Well, you have to simply tell me, that's all.

Speaker: second engineer
Dialogue: That's exactly what I am doing, again.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Do you have to let me get halfway through the movement first? This is tiring me.

Speaker: second engineer
Dialogue: I have a suggestion. Why don't we take a break.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Oh, for pity's sake...

Speaker: first engineer
Dialogue: Is she going to cry again?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: I don't want to take a break.

Speaker: second engineer
Dialogue: What would you like in your coffee?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Tea.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Would you tell her Bobby's here?

Speaker: second engineer
Dialogue: Miss Dupea, Bobby's here.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Oh my goodness... Bobby...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Hi, Tita.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Robert Eroica...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Now don't...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: No, I'm not...  I'm not.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: That's good.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: I just can't look at you.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Don't, then.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: You always do this to me.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well, I don't mean to.  Here's your tea, Tita.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Thank you...  Oh no, don't put it on there...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: This is a very special, very old CB

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: You know who it once belonged to?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Waldnit von Schnechter. Prewar.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No kidding.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: It has absolutely no objectionable idiosyncrasies...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Very nice.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: I have to talk seriously with you...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Everybody still up on the Island?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Well, Herbert's mostly on the mainland because of the orchestra, so at the moment, there's just Daddy, Carl and myself... and Van Oost.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Who's Van Oost?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Catherine -- she's a pianist. She's working with Carl.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Carl's a fiddler. What's he doing coaching piano?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Well, 11 months ago he was on his bicycle, on his way to the post office in La Roche... and he ran into a Jeep and sprained his neck...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Sprained his neck?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: It's not funny. He permanently sprained his neck, and since then it's been extremely difficult for him to tuck the violin.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Crashes into a Jeep and totals his neck.  That's Carl...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Robert, I have to tell you something...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Daddy's very ill.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Oh, well, what, what's he...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: He's had two strokes.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Don't tell me about this...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: But don't you think it's right, though, that you should see him, at least once...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Robert, don't you think it's right that you should see him?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah... I guess so...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: I'm going back up tonight. Will you go with me?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well...  I better let you...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Wait...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: They hate me, I feel.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Maybe you better stay, then.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: No, I need to talk to you, about so many things...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well, I'll be seeing you in a couple of days, won't I?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Oh God, I'm so glad, Robert, that you're coming...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah, me, too...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: It'll be so good for you, and for Daddy, because you know, you've never really...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Tita, I've got to go...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: All right...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Hello?!

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You'll be gone, period.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'll try and call you from up there.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Do you want to go with me, Ray?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: "There's been hot spells/An' cold spells ever since we met/I've seen your small fires/Your big fires/But I won't give up yet/Oh someday you'll yearn/'Cause your heart's gonna burn/For that old familiar glow/You'll be burned..."

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I love it.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: "You'll be burned out/Or smoked out/An' come back to me, I know..."

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What the hell is that?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Is it an accident?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Hey! What's going on, what's the trouble?!

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Rotate, mack!

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: What'd she say?

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Look at my car! Piece of shit! I just bought it brand new from a used-car lot, and the steering goes to the pot on me!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You're lucky no one was hurt.

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Seven hundred dollars, down the toilet! I'd like to go back and punch the son of a bitch out! Can you give us a lift?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Jesus, what a rude person...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What's your name?

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Palm Apodaca.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: An' what's your name?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Terry Grouse.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: How far are you going to?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Washington.

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: We'll get off in Washington and hook another ride.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Alaska.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Alaska? Are you on vacation?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: She wants to live there, because she thinks it's cleaner.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Cleaner than what?

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: You don't have to tell everybody about it. Pretty soon they'll all go there and it won't be so clean.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: How do you know it's clean?

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: I saw a picture of it. Alaska is very clean. It appeared to look very white to me... Don't you think?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah. That's before the big thaw.

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Before the what?

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: I had to leave this place. I got depressed, seeing all the crap. And the thing is, they're making more crap, you know? They've got so many stores and stuff and junk full of crap, I can't believe it.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Who? People, that's who! Pretty soon there won't be room for anyone. They're selling more crap that people go and buy than you can imagine. Oofh! Crap! I believe everybody should have a big hole where they throw in all this stuff and burn it.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: There'd never be a hole big enough. Now took at me, for instance, when I was just one person, before Bobby, I had so much garbage collectin' onto me every day, I was thinkin' about gettin a dispose all...

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: A dispose-all, what's that but more crap? I've never seen such crap. Oofh, I don't know how people get up in the morning.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Mass production is what does it.

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: What do you mean "mass"... I have to come out and tell you, you're not that clean, either.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Wait a minute. I'm not that neat, maybe, but I am clean.

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Well, you're not that bad, but some people... I mean, people's homes, just filth. I've been in people's homes...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: In my personal observation, I think that more people are neat than are clean...

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: In my personal thing, I don't see that. I'm seeing more filth. A lot of filth. What they need to do every day, no, once in a while, is a cockroach thing, where they spray the homes. And uh... can you imagine, if their doors were painted a pretty color, and they had a pot outside, with...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, it could be adorable...

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: And they picked up! I mean, it wouldn't be filthy, with Coke bottles and whiskey, and those signs everywhere...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well...

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: It's just filthy. People are dirty. I think that's the biggest thing that's wrong with people. I think they wouldn't be as violent if they were clean, because then they wouldn't have anybody to pick on... Oofh... Dirt...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Well...

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Not dirt. See, dirt isn't bad. It's filth. Filth is bad. That's what starts maggots and riots...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: That's an old maid's tale.

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Bullshit! Truck drivers know the best eating places on the road.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Salesmen and cops are the ones. If you'd ever waitressed, honey, you'd know.

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Don't call me "honey," mack.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Don't call me "mack," honey.

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: I wouldn't be a waitress. They're nasty and full of crap.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You better hold onto your tongue!

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Hold onto this.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Just one minute, you! Don't you ever talk to me like that!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Shut up! All of you!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'll have an omelette, no potatoes. Give me tomatoes instead, and wheat toast instead of rolls.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: No substitutions.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What does that mean? You don't have any tomatoes?

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: No. We have tomatoes.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: But I can't have any. Is that what you mean?

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Only what's on the menu...  A Number Two: Plain omelette. It comes with cottage fries and rolls.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I know what it comes with, but that's not what I want.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: I'll come back when you've made up your mind...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Wait, I've made up my mind. I want a plain omelette, forget the tomatoes, don't put potatoes on the plate, and give me a side of wheat toast and a cup of coffee.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: I'm sorry, we don't have side orders of toast. I can give you an English muffin or a coffee roll.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What do you mean, you don't have side orders of toast? You make sandwiches, don't you?

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Would you like to talk to the manager?

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Hey, mack!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You have bread, don't you, and a toaster of some kind?

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: I don't make the rules.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Okay, I'll make it as easy for you as I can. Give me an omelette, plain, and a chicken salad sandwich on wheat toast -- no butter, no mayonnaise, no lettuce -- and a cup of coffee.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: One Number Two, and a chicken sal san -- hold the butter, the mayo, the lettuce -- and a cup of coffee... Anything else?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Now all you have to do is hold the chicken, bring me the toast, charge me for the sandwich, and you haven't broken any rules.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: You want me to hold the chicken.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah. I want you to hold it between your knees.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: You see that sign, sir?!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You see this sign?

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Fantastic! That you could figure all that out, and lay that down on her, to come up with a way you could get your toast.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I didn't get it, did I?

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: No, but it was very clever... I would of just punched her out.

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: People... Oofh...  Animals are not like that... They're always cleaning themselves. Did you ever see... What are they called? Pigeons!

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Except monkeys do things out in the open that I don't go for.

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: I was in this place once, this store, with snakes, monkeys, everything you could imagine. I walked in, I had to run out. It stunk! They didn't even have an incense going...

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: And you know, I read where they invented this car that runs on... that runs on... when you boil water...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Steam.

Speaker: palm
Dialogue: Right, steam. A car you could ride around in and not cause a stink. But do you know, they will not even let us have it. Can you believe it? Why?! Man! He likes to create a stink. I wrote them a note once, and told them to clean it... I mean, don't you see that? It's just filthy! I mean, I've seen filth you wouldn't believe! Oofh, what a stink! I don't even want to talk about it...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Are you depressed about your daddy, honey?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I 'magine it's me then, id'n it?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Is what you?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You're depressed that I come along.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Who said I was depressed?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Well, is that a happy face I see?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Oh, you're not going to kill yourself this time. I wish I'd known...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I don't know if I'm gonna be able to sleep or not.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: If you just wouldn't open your mouth, everything would be fine.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Tick a lock.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Why can't I go out to your folks' house? Give me one good reason.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I have to see how things are first. My father's sick, you understand? They wouldn't be prepared for me bringing anyone.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: So how long am I supposed to sit an' twiddle my thumbs in this place?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: If you can't do what I ask, Ray, use that money to go back home, then.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Bobby, don't talk like that...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Okay, Ray...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Or maybe sit out by the pool an' get myself nice an' tan for you. Would you like that?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Sure...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: It brings out my eyes...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Bye, honey, I'll call you in a couple of days.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Okay...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: He doesn't even know who the hell I am.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Remember, Bobby, what mother used to say when...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Oh, excuse me...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: No, it's all right, you go ahead...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I was just going to ask Robert how long he's been away from here.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Four or five years.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: No, the last time was three years ago.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Oh no, it's been much more than that.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Away from the piano, Tita, you have no sense of time at all.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: I don't think that's true.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: It is true.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Besides being very rude.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: What have you been doing since then?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What have I been doing? Different things, different jobs, here and there. Nothing that interesting.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: And you no longer play at all?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: You know, just after I came back off tour with the Betenthaller Quartet, Dad, myself and Herbert had a summit conference about you...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Oh, my, "a summit conference." I wonder where I was, polishing silver behind the coal bin.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: I don't know where you were, penis envy.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: I hope I didn't hear that.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: At any rate, Dad wanted to hire a private detective to ferret you out, and I said, "What for?" Whatever the hell he's doing, even if it's a completely wasteful escapade, it's entirely his business. Simple as that...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well, I really appreciate it, Carl.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: I don't think you should infer Daddy was wrong in front of him...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: How long have you been staying here?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: A couple of months.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Did you hear about my misfortune, Robert?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: It's still nearly impossible for me to turn my neck. If I wanted to turn toward Catherine, for instance, I'd first have to twist the whole base of my body around...  ... like this...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I wouldn't mind doing a little work, if you're finished, and not too tired...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: No, I'm finished...  Satiety is my father and mother.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Is she?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Excuse me, I don't want to hear this...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: I hope you feel at home, Robert.  I'm really glad you're here.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Thanks, Carl...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: He has ways of communicating, Robert. I can tell when he's expressing approval or disapproval, just from his eyes...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Uhm hmm. Some range.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: It's not that bad.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yes, it is. I can't take seeing him, sitting there like a stone.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: A week or two isn't going to ruin your life, for Godsakes.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No, I don't.  You should've left a long time ago.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: We can't all get up and leave, can we? I mean, there are certain needs you have to respond to...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What questions?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Well, do you -- I mean, have you enjoyed all these... strange things you've been doing?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Sometimes.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: No, no, I don't think that, I'm just curious about it...  Do you think I'm a freak?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Sort of.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Oh no... Why? What is it? The way I look?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No, I don't really think you're a freak.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: I probably am, but I don't care. I mean, I wasn't that blessed to begin with, and when would I have had time to make any improvements...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What about Carl and Catherine? Is he just coaching her, or what?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Constantly. Night and day. And unless I get up before the birds, I can't get in any practice time for myself...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Uhm hmm.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Actually, it's very admirable, the way she works. She'll probably be enormously successful, because she's attractive as well, not that that's so important in music, but...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You're attractive, Tita. If you just did a little more with yourself...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well, if you just maybe did something with your hair, or...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Oh, let's not talk about my hair, it does what it wants to, and anyway, who cares, I want to talk about you...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: There's nothing to say, Tita...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Well, you're not going to run out on me right away, are you?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Oh God, don't sneak up on me like that!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Hello...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I guess you fell in the water.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Yes, intentionally.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: That's dangerous, you know.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Swimming?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Playing piano all day and then jumping into cold water. You could get a cramp.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I love to swim, and I don't mind the cold at all. It's invigorating.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Well, I wouldn't want to get too invigorated myself.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What would I do with it? Run amok?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Well, there's fishing and boating. There's concerts on the mainland and... but I feel silly telling you. This is really your home. You probably know better than I what there is to do.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Nothing? Then it must be very boring for you here.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: That's right. Have you anything to suggest?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I don't know. Let me give it some thought.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What're you doing right now...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Right now I'm going to run a hot tub and soak myself.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Then after that?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: After that, I plan to read some music and rest for awhile.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Tomorrow, then.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Tomorrow's a full practice day...  But the day after is kind of open.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: The day after tomorrow.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: If you're free.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah, I'll probably be free.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Don't laugh...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: I took some aspirin and it really upset my stomach.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: One thing that's hard to understand is how you could have this incredible background in music, and then just walk away from it, without a second thought...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I gave it a second thought.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: He looks tired to me, Spicer. I think you should put him to bed.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I mean, how could you not play anymore? That's so strange to me...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I have played a few times. Here and there. As a matter of fact, I was once a rehearsal pianist for a Las Vegas musical revue.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: You don't call that music, though.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Of course I do. It's music. You know...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Robert, do you mind?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Nothing. Will you excuse us for a while?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: We really don't have to, Carl, if you're not feeling good...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Well, maybe if we put the Thermaphore on me for a while, first...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Oh, all right.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Do you want some gingerbread?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: With applesauce?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No, thanks...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah, well fine, you know what I suggest, Ray...  Because I don't know how long. Things are not going that well here...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Only 10 minutes of playing and it's already killing my neck...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You sure you should be playing, Carl?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: What do you mean? Aside from my neck, I'm in superb shape.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I don't know, there's something wrong with the way you move.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: I'm not aware of it. Like what?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Your serve. Two -- Eighteen.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: I've walked across a stage a number of times, without exciting any particular response...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: That's what I mean...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Any particular humor, I meant.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I think you should get someone to coach you how to walk. I think it's a substantial problem.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Dammit!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Look at that.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Why are you being so mean?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'm not. He does walk funny. Don't you see that?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: I don't think I'd notice. I'm so used to Carl.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah, well, he's...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Bobby? Do you think Spicer is attractive?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I think he's got a terrific personality.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: You know, he was formerly a sailor.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Look, can't you see that, what I'm talking about?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Sailors are sadistic, I feel.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: See? There's nothing wrong with the way I walk. Now where are we?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: At game, Carl.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: All right, let's have a rematch.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I thought you had to go to the mainland today. Aren't you going to miss the ferry?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Too bad. Just when I was hitting my stride.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Can I play now?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Tell her I'll be back sometime tomorrow!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Where is she, anyway?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: My turn.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Why don't you and Spicer play?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: That was beautiful, Robert. I'm surprised...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I was really very moved by the way you...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: It wasn't supposed to be, it just struck me that way.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Nothing. It's just that... I picked the easiest piece I could remember. I think I first played it when I was 8 years old and I played it better then.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: It doesn't matter. It was the feeling I was affected by.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I didn't have any.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: You had no inner feeling?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: None.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Then I must have been supplying it.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Wait...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Well, at least you're accomplished at something...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: At being a fake.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Catherine...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: No, you're very good at it. I'm really impressed.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Shit.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You think I'm a fake.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I think it's what you think.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No, it isn't what I think.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Look... You made a very calculated move, and then made me feel embarrassed for responding to you. That wasn't necessary.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yes, it was. You've made it clear that if I can cut a little piano, I might get a little response.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I don't think that's accurate...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Up to now, what I've been getting from you are meaningful looks over the dinner table and a lot of vague suggestions about the day after tomorrow...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I'm not conscious of having given you any meaningful looks. And as for the day after tomorrow, this is the day after tomorrow, and I am, unfortunately, seeing you... Now if you'll excuse me, I'd like to take a bath.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: It's convenient to fake looking for something right now, isn't it?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I'm not faking anything. I'm looking for some bath oil...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Some bath oil?

Speaker: cathfrine
Dialogue: What are you doing!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What are you doing, screwing around with this crap?!

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I don't find your language that charming.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: It's direct, anyway, which seems to be difficult for you.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I'd like you to leave now. Is that direct enough?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Serious, that's what's important to you?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Yes, that's what's important to me...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Okay, let's be serious...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: No, don't do that...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Shut up...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: No inner feeling.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I don't believe vou.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I married him when I was 17. He was a cellist, and I thought he was the most brilliant man I'd ever met... And I'm sure he was, because at that age, I hadn't met that many... But he was insidious, you know. He had me convinced that I was a mediocrity, musically, as a woman, as an intellect. But in this completely imperceptible, pleasant way, so that you weren't even sure he was doing it. Anyway, I just woke up one morning and I said, you know something Joseph, you're full of beans, and I left him...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: That's what you said?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Something witty and devastating like that.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'm fine.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Carl restored my confidence. He really did. He's much more substantial than you give him credit for.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Is he?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah, I think I could.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Robert?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I could spend some time with you tomorrow morning, before Carl comes back, I mean, if you'd like to.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Of course I'd like to.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You certainly do have a beautiful piece a real estate out here, Mr. Dupea.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Can he hear me?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: He's not hard of hearing.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Well, that's a blessing, at least.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: You've been staying in a motel all this time?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: For two whole weeks, an' there wasn't hardly nobody there to talk to but me. The manager of the place told me it was the off season, an' it must a ben, because other'n me, there was just this 25-year-old kid, DeLyon, that didn't appear to be all there, an' this old married pair next to me that was always hollerin' for quiet. Can you imagine? All you could a heard there was a pin, an' them, hollerin' away...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: I don't understand why you had to stay in a motel. There's more than enough room here.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Well, I was goin' to, but Bobby said he hadda kind of feel things up here first, which I can understand, but then it went an' took so long, I ran flat outa money...  So I hadda clear outa there an' come on up here, in the hopes that I wouldn't be intrudin' myself...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Oh, no. You're more than welcome.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Well, thank you, that's a very nice thing for you to say.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Not at all.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: That certainly is a beautiful head a hair you have.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Is it natural?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Rayette.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Just finish eating.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Oh, am I holdin' up dessert?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: No, you're not. Go ahead and take your time.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I do eat slow as a bird, whereas Bobby can put it away like a speed swing...  Is there any ketchup around?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Oh, for chrissakes...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Robert, let's not be rude, okay?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: It's all right. He don't mean anything by that.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I don't, huh?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I guess Bobby's just about the moodiest man I ever ben with...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I'm going to pick up some friends of Carl's. Are you all right?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I have to talk to you.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I'll be back later...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No, I want to talk to you now. I have to explain something about...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: No, you don't have to, it isn't necessary...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yes, it is!

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Come on, get moving, dammit!!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Pull your car out of line.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: No, I can't...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Will you let me talk to you, please?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I can't do that. I haven't been being fair to Carl. I have to tell you that.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Oh. You have to tell me that.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: What?! I can't hear you!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Catherine...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Please, I'll see you later this evening.

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: But the point is, man is born into the world with a pre-existent adversary, both real and imaginary, so you'd have to say that aggression was one of his primary, psychic inheritances, which...

Speaker: fincher
Dialogue: If I may beg to differ...

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: Beg all you like, John, but the fact remains that man takes enormous delight in aggressive acts, as well as the portrayal of aggressive acts, and to be triumphant over another no matter how, seems fundamental to his having a sense of well being, as well as...

Speaker: fincher
Dialogue: No, I don't quarrel with your inference, but you draw too long a bow in your conclusions, which seem unnecessarily harsh and...

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: Well, I don't make poetry. As an analyst, I...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Is there a TV in the house?

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: John believes in the basic goodness of man, and that's fine, but gaze into the pit like I have and that view seems a little soporific. And not unlike television, it hardly represents the real world...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: There's some good things on it, though.

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: Pardon me?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: The TV. There's some good things on it, sometimes.

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: I strongly doubt it, but I wasn't really discussing media...

Speaker: fincher
Dialogue: If you really hold such bleak views, how can you, in good conscience, carry on a practice?

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: Oh, there's always hope, I think, for a few individuals, if they're courageous enough to shed their illusions and their...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: And what about love?

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: What about it? Wouldn't you agree that a great deal of mischief has been done in the name of love?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: No, I wouldn't.

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: Well, you're a romantic, Catherine, as are most musicians, and what's more, about to be married...

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: ... which should exclude you from any objective discussion. But keep in mind, even the arts aren't free of aggressive content, nor the institution of marriage.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I think these cold, "objective" discussions are aggressive, Samia...

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: But I'd like to say, so that I don't dampen the spirit of your adventure...

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: You haven't dampened my spirit, Samia... Excuse me.

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: Well, I should hope not...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: What kind of doggy is that?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: It's a Borzoi.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Oh, uh huh. I had a little kittycat once, that Bobby give me...

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: There. You see what I mean?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Well, she was.

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: Perhaps...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Don't sit there pointing at her.

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: I beg your pardon.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I said, don't point at her like that! What gives you the right to sit there and tell anybody about class and who the hell's got it, and what she typifies! You shouldn't even be in the same room with her, you creep!

Speaker: samia
Dialogue: Carl, this is really too much...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You're totally full of shit!

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Robert, I think you better just...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: You're all full of shit!

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Bobby...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I can't talk to you right now, leave me alone...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Tita, what the hell are you doing?!

Speaker: spicer
Dialogue: Hey, this is my room.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: What's going on here!?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: It's none of your business!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Where's Catherine?!

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: I don't know where she is!

Speaker: spicer
Dialogue: Don't you believe in knocking, pal?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'm talking to you, Tita!

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Can't I have anything to myself, dammit?!

Speaker: spicer
Dialogue: Come on now, out!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Keep your fucking hands off my sister, nurse!

Speaker: spicer
Dialogue: Did you hear me! Move out!!

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Stop it! Bobby, will just you stop! I mean it!

Speaker: spicer
Dialogue: Hold it, just hold it!!

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Carl! Somebody get Carl!

Speaker: spicer
Dialogue: Take it easy, dammit!

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Stop it! Right now! Just stop it!! Carl!!

Speaker: spicer
Dialogue: Give up! Give up! Give up! Give up! Give up! Give up!

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Oh God, Bobby, look what you've done...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I just wanted to talk to you for a minute.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: No. It's useless, Robert. It wouldn't work, not ever...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Just give me a chance, will you?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I'm trying to be delicate with you, but you're not understanding me. It's not just because of Carl, or my music, but because of you...  I mean, what would it come to? If a person has no love for himself, no respect, no love for his work, his family, his friends, something... How can he ask for love in return? I mean, why should he ask for it?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: And living out here, in this rest home asylum, that's what you want?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: That'll make you happy.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I hope it will, yes.  I'm sorry.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Are you cold?

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Bobby!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Yeah. I said a week, and I've overstayed myself...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: You were going without saying goodbye?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I didn't want to say goodbye to anyone.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: But what about me?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: I'll say goodbye to you, Tita.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Just once in a while, call and tell me where you are, please...

Speaker: rayette's voice
Dialogue: Watch the birdie!

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Bye, now.

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Bye, Robert.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Wait a sec. I want Tita to take a picture of you an' me in front of the place...

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No, let's go...

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I never got the chance to thank you all for your hospitality. You tell Carl for me, if any of you folks wanta come on down to our place anytime, you'd be more'n welcome...

Speaker: tita
Dialogue: Thank you, that's very nice.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Bye bye, now.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: "Your kiss is like a drink when I'm thirsty/An' I'm thirsty for you with all my heart..."

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: "But don't love me/Then act as though we've never kissed/Oh, don't touch me..."

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Cut it out!

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Son of a bitch, Bobby! You quit pushin' me away like that! I've had enough a that to last me a lifetime!

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: I'm gonna go in that cafe an' get some coffee. You want anything?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: You got any change?

Speaker: rayette
Dialogue: Sure you don't want anything?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Fill it up.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Hey, wait a minute.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Haven't you got a jacket or anything with you?

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No, I don't, I uh... it got burned up. Everything in the car got the shit burned out of it. All I got left is what I have on...

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: I've got an extra jacket behind the seat, if you want to put it on.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: No, it's okay.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Suit yourself. But I'll tell you, where we're headed is gonna get colder'n hell.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: It's all right. I'm fine.
